passage:
(1) Volcanoes are powerful natural phenomena that dramatically alter landscapes throughout the world. When a volcano erupts, it releases molten rock called lava, as well as ash and various gases from deep within the Earth. These materials can drastically transform the surrounding environment, creating entirely new landforms over time. The process might be destructive initially, but volcanic activity contributes significantly to the creation of fertile soil and diverse ecosystems.

(2) One of the most visible ways volcanoes shape landscapes is through the formation of mountains and islands. Stratovolcanoes, such as Mount Fuji in Japan, are built up layer by layer through multiple eruptions, eventually creating tall, conical mountains. In contrast, shield volcanoes, like those found in Hawaii, form more gradually from highly fluid lava flows, resulting in gentler slopes and broader structures. In ocean environments, underwater volcanic eruptions can create new islands, adding landmass to our planet.

(3) Beyond creating new landforms, volcanic activity also contributes to the development of unique geological features. Hot springs and geysers form when groundwater is heated by underground magma chambers. These features not only create distinctive landscapes but also support specialized ecosystems. Additionally, calderas—large depressions formed when a volcano collapses after an eruption—can fill with water to create stunning crater lakes that become central features of the landscape.

(4) The soil created by volcanic eruptions is particularly rich in minerals, making volcanic regions some of the most fertile agricultural areas on Earth. As volcanic ash and lava break down over time, they release valuable nutrients into the soil. Many of the world's most productive farming regions, from Italy's volcanic plains to the slopes of Indonesian volcanoes, owe their fertility to ancient or ongoing volcanic activity. These nutrient-rich soils support diverse plant life, which in turn attracts various animal species.

(5) While volcanic eruptions can be destructive in the short term, they ultimately play a vital role in the continuous renewal of Earth's surface. Without volcanic activity, many of our planet's most distinctive landscapes would not exist. From the dramatic peaks of mountainous regions to the lush ecosystems surrounding volcanic lakes, the impact of volcanoes on our environment is profound and far-reaching. By understanding how volcanoes shape landscapes, scientists can better comprehend the complex geological processes that continue to transform our planet.

questions.question: Which sentence is grammatically correct?

options.B: I have went to that restaurant before.
options.C: They are studying for their exam right now.

questions.question: Choose the correct sentence:

options.A: He has been living in this city since five years.
options.B: She has been living in this city for five years.
options.C: They have been living in this city during five years.
options.D: We have been living in this city by five years.

questions.question: Select the sentence with the correct verb tense:

options.A: I will finishing the project tomorrow.
options.B: We are go to the beach next weekend.
options.C: He didn't watched the movie last night.
options.D: They will be arriving at 6 PM.

options.A: The cake was eating by the children.
options.B: The cake is eaten by the children.
options.C: The cake was eaten by the children.
options.D: The cake were eaten by the children.

questions.question: Which of the following is grammatically correct?

options.A: Neither John or Mary was at the party.
options.B: Neither John nor Mary were at the party.
options.C: Neither John nor Mary was at the party.
options.D: Neither John and Mary was at the party.

questions.question: Select the sentence with correct subject-verb agreement:

options.A: The number of students in the class are increasing.
options.B: A number of students is absent today.
options.C: The number of students in the class is increasing.

options.D: This book is the most interesting than that one.

options.D: He is more smarter than his brother.

options.A: Despite of the rain, we went for a walk.
options.B: Although it was raining, we went for a walk.
options.C: Even though it was raining, but we went for a walk.
options.D: In spite it was raining, we went for a walk.

questions.question: According to paragraph 1, what is lava?

options.C: A new landform created by volcanoes

options.C: Underwater volcanoes

options.C: A depression formed when a volcano collapses

options.A: They receive more rainfall than other areas
options.C: Ash and lava release nutrients into the soil
options.D: Farmers use special techniques in these areas

questions.question: What is the main idea of paragraph 5?

options.B: Volcanoes play a vital role in renewing Earth's surface
options.C: Scientists cannot predict volcanic eruptions
options.D: Most distinctive landscapes have no connection to volcanoes

questions.question: The word 'phenomena' in paragraph 1 is closest in meaning to:

options.C: Theories

options.A: They are too dangerous for human habitation

options.D: They experience more rainfall than other areas

questions.question: The author's purpose in writing this passage is to:

options.C: Compare different types of volcanoes
options.D: Describe famous volcanic eruptions throughout history
